page.title: 01GEOGRAPHY AND ECOLOGY
page.content: HOLME LIES IN THE VALLEY OF THE RIVER BELA AT THE FOOT OF CLAWTHORPE AND FARLETON FELL.THE LAND ON WHICH HOLME IS BUILT IS FERTILE FARM LAND AND THE ORIGINAL VILLAGE CONSISTED OF 5 FARMS NOW JOINED TOGETHER BY MODERN ROADS ALONG WHICH HAVE BEEN BUILT HOUSES.THE CHURCH WAS BUILT IN 1840 AT THE MAIN ROAD JUNCTION.EAST OF THE VILLAGE THE HILLS WHICH RISE TO 800 FEET ARE MADE OF LIMESTONE.THE LIMESTONE IS QUARRIED AT HOLME QUARRY.SOME OF CLAWTHORPE FELL HAS WORN BY THE WEATHER INTO LIMESTONE STEPS.THIS IS A PROTECTED AREA WHERE RARE PLANTS GROW. RUNNING NORTH TO SOUTH THROUGH THE VILLAGE IS THE LANCASTER CANAL.IN THE NINETEENTH CENTURY THIS WAS A BUSY WATER WAY JOINING KENDAL AND LANCASTER BUT THE CANAL NOW FINISHES AT THE NORTH END OF THE VILLAGE. POPULATION 1100, STATIC FOR TEN YEARS.
